comments.commentBody:
My relatives in Germany, which is now facing a surge in right-wing activity due to the recent refugee/migration surge, ask me HOW is someone like Trump possible in America???
I tell them to look at history, which now seems to be repeating itself -- but hopefully this timewith a different outcome.
Anything else is too frightening to contemplate.
My concern is how much damage will he do after he loses the election?
Its only logical that the Great Orange Projector who is facing multiple felony court dates in the next few months would be such a nasty, nasty guy.

replies.commentBody: jorgeuox--Now, let's make sure Little Marco and wasTED can't run, either.

comments.commentBody: "Read my lips". Mr. Trump ain't going to be elected, When the next opportunity comes, he ll be past his prime age to run.

Well okay, the Republicans may well hold the House but what's that gonna look like? Will there be enough Freedom Caucus members to deny Ryan the Speakership? If he needs their votes they will surely come with a big price tag & if Ryan isn't willing to give 'em what they want, then what? Can the House function without a Speaker? I guess I don't think so. Could we end up with 3 parties in the House?

Would such a mess finally persuade enough Americans to throw the bums out in 2018? I know, the Democrats have had a hard time getting their voters to turn out for mid-term elections but that's not an immutable law of politics.

replies.commentBody: Desperate ones. Those who have no jobs or hope for one. Clean air and water has become more popular than whatever kept them employed. We need s jobs program for those displaced by our need for a better world.

Without clean air and water there is no better world.
And in most cases, people will probably need re-education programs before even being considered qualified to get a job.

Tired Liberal and N. Smith--None of that stuff will be done under the Republicans.  They have no consciences, and no love for our country, or democracy.  They love money and autocracy.  "More of the same" means continued Republican control of Congress.  Vote DEMOCRAT, all the way down the ballot, and start thinking about the critical election, two years from now!  We can only save ourselves if we save our democratic republic.

comments.commentBody:
I just can't help but be struck by the photo here. Up above the stage is a bald eagle, clutching arrows and olive branches, that we should all be pretty familiar with. It's got a sign too, "The Union and the Constitution", two things that I believe in.

Donald would undo the Union if he loses, fighting a free and fair vote by our citizens.

Donald knows nothing about the Constitution and his words often spit upon it.

What kind of American votes for this ignorant fascist?

replies.commentBody: They didn't really like Bernie they were just anti-Hillary trying to pull the wool over your eyes.
And for die-hard Trump supporters, don't return down ballot Republicans to Congress. If you really want change, vote them out.

@DD
But don't you find it somehow odd that all of a sudden, Trump is talking about Bernie Sanders ???
A divisive tactic if ever I've seen one.

comments.commentBody:
If those who support Trump but do not consider themselves die-hard deplorable would take a moment or two to catch their breath and retain their composure they might see the real culprit in their plight of stagnant wages, low growth and crumbling infrastructure. They might take a look to see what the Republicans have been doing since the days of Reagan. The middle class has been suffering since then and after three plus decades its toll should become more evident to the average worker, yes, especially the those who see Trump as their savior. Many of them also liked what Bernie Sanders had to say about their plight. Senator Sanders actually had solutions to their problems and that is why many who weren't afraid of embracing the label of "Socialist" could see the merits in many of Bernie's proposals. They should also see that Hillary is more closely aligned with Bernie than Trump ever could be. In fact the reason is wholeheartedly campaigning for Hillary is to make sure Trump is defeated, and there may at least be a chance of getting some of his legislation passed.

Now, Trumpists, that may be a lot to handle at this late stage, that the Dems have had the interests of the working poor and middle class more so than Republicans have had with their trickle-down massive tax cuts for the rich philosophy. We've been doing that since '80. How's it been working?

DD
Manhattan

replies.commentBody: Well said.  It's incredible that Obama was able to accomplish anything at all with both houses of Congress controlled by obstructionists, yet he actually made an impact.  Hopefully the voters will give Hillary a better shot at progress.

comments.commentBody: Trump supporters who are angry that Washington doesn't work should focus on the real cause for this failure--the GOP representatives and senators who refuse to compromise on most issues.  The GOP's senators are even refusing to follow the Constitution and consider the President's nominee for the Supreme Court.  As one conservative scholar has written, this unwillingness to work with the other party is unprecedented.  Much of this problem can be traced to Gingrich who introduced the idea of using extreme language to refer to the Democrats such as the "enemy."  This election the voters need to show that they want representatives who will make our government work, who will not try to make it fail.

replies.commentBody: The frightening thing about this election is that - despite Trump being completely unqualified - millions of Americans are going to vote for him.  Millions.  The fact that he's made it this far is an embarrassment to our country in the eyes of the world.  Disgusting.

comments.commentBody:
Sensible, reasonable people are amazed that the campaign is this close, it really should be a blowout! If all the women who have had negative interactions with Mr. Trump came forward, it would probably require 2 pages just to name them all.

Putting that aside and looking at real stuff to focus on; Mr. Trump is so ill-equipped for the job that it is a joke to even realistically conceive. Given that he will probably lose miserably, the thing to address is how to get Congress to do something worthwhile.

Congress gets paid well and they do nothing! They sat on the Obama Supreme Court nominee for 2+ months now we face a contentious election with an ill-tempered buffoon determined that he will take it to the Supreme Court if he does not win. With a divided court, all manners of mayhem is possible.

Ladies and Gentlemen, the GOP caused this and they should be held accountable. Voting a straight Democratic ticket would send a message; "We sent you to DC to conduct business and you did not do that so we are replacing you. Goodbye and don't call us, let us call you."

replies.commentBody: It's not just a matter of gerrymandering. Since Democratic voters are packed in the big cities, with a districts mayority system it's unavoidable to receive less seats than proportional votes. Unless a democratic gerrymandering system could be put in place (district with portion of big cities and portion of countryside even very far from the cities). But this it'would not be very fair too...

comments.commentBody: Talk about a rigged system:  House districts have been so gerrymandered that Democrats would have to have around 55% in the generic congressional ballot to have a chance of winning a majority.  The Republicans will, of course, engage in their usual antics, such a shutting down the government and voting to overturn the Affordable Care Act for the  100th time.  But that kind of deliberate gridlocking hasn't work so well for them, since the incapacity of the Congress to engage in governance helped to fuel the rise of Donald Trump.  Let's hope, if they maintain control, they will rethink their approach to things.
Signs of a Trump comeback??? -- Can't imagine how he'd pull that off, considering he has no standing after shooting himself in both feet.

replies.commentBody: I second that apology.
Me too.
Ditto.

comments.commentBody: Up here in Canada, I am holding my breath. On Nov. 8, if we hear that Hillary Clinton has won a significant majority, not just Americans, but the entire world will collectively and deeply exhale.
Seriously, you're predicting? No one has called this right since last June.

To all those voters who see this as a Change election: You want to see Change? Vote the Republicans out of the Senate and Vote the Republicans out of the House! You will see true change in Washington.

replies.commentBody:
"[Mr Trump]...said little if anything about his own proposals or vision for the country."

You, pshawhan1, are a very intelligent person! I wish all Americans had such keen senses. The Trumpet would have no fan base by now. I use the word "fan" because it connotes adulation of the basest sort, rather than "supporter," which assumes intellectual admiration for a potential leader.

What kind of people are ga-ga over this clown?

comments.commentBody:
The last two minutes of the final debate served to sum up this campaign. Secretary Clinton spoke about where she wanted to take the country, talked about uniting people, and asked for voters' support. Mr. Trump spent his last minute attacking Secretary Clinton in harsh terms, and said little if anything about his own proposals or vision for the country.

I have strong feelings about which of these two would be a better President, and am tempted to express them in blunt terms, but this campaign has seen more than enough intemperate language. Suffice it to say that, regardless of what polls currently show, there is far too much at stake in this election for anyone to be complacent. I will be absolutely sure to vote on Election Day, and I will express my opinion by casting my vote.

Con Don never could dream that he could win Republican nomination. But the unthinkable happened with the use of his skills as a reality TV star. Lies after lies and bullying helped him to win. He was never prepared to win any contest. But, it is the misdeeds of the Grand Obstrauction Party helped him to make it happen. A mouthpiece for paymasters, the party has not done a single thing for us,the common people. Gerrymandering, creating division and race baiting helped the party to win elections at the cost of the destruction of the nation. Well, it cannot last for long. What goes around comes around. And, Con Don won. He took advantage of the anger of the people. But he is the wrong bogey man- he is a free loader, bully with no respect for anyone but himself. Let him loss by a landslide so that a caricature like him will never consider to run in the future. Simply, con Don is a disgrace for the entire humankind.

replies.commentBody: me too

@steve
Saying the entire election cycle is "rigged" just because you're losing sounds more like Sour Grapes than anything remotely Constitutional.
Oh. That's right.
Trump knows NOTHING about the U.S. Constitution.
Never mind.

@steve
I disgree. That "rigging" myth is a fabrication of a desperate candidate who has no chance of winning the majority vote (he's already insulted HALF of the electorate, remember???) -- and a right-wing media that thrives on conspiracies and lies.
The "worst possible person in the White House" would be Donald Trump, and Clinton can't do worse to him, than what he's doing to himself.

comments.commentBody:
Secretary Clinton needs to stick to the high ground and continue to flesh out her agenda. Just enough to reassure those voting for her they have made the right decision. Mrs. Clinton should point out those members of the GOP, especially those in leadership positions, that continue to support Mr. Trump because the party comes before the nation. Mr. Trump on the other hand will continue his quest to the center of the earth as his attacks on Mrs. Clinton become increasingly personal and ugly.
We begin early voting in Texas next Monday and I will be at the polling station with registration card and picture id (passport) in hand bright and early.

replies.commentBody: I agree.  I am a registered independent because I usually split my choices between the parties.  This year I refuse to vote for anyone running under the banner of the party that nominated Donald Trump.

I can't think of a Republican that I would've never voted for.
The smartest one in my lifetime was Nixon. But he was mean spirited also. I don't think there's been one worth avoiding for since Eisenhower. And to be a Republican now mean spirited has to be your middle name.

comments.commentBody:
In the past, I would occasionally vote for a Republican. But the GOP has become so extreme and moved away from its earlier positions now that I will probably never vote for a Republican again. At one point, the GOP supported the environment, a woman's right to choose, civil rights, sensible gun control, and other positions. Pulled to the extreme right by the tea party, the NRA, and the religious right, it is no longer the party that it once was. Instead of being a big tent, it is a big black hole sucking up its previous support of American values and being nihilistic. Its politicians shut down the government, obstruct the president, hold endless investigations about the same issues, want to repeal the healthcare of 20 million+ fellow Americans, block judicial appointments, and vote against basic infrastructure repair and other priorities that used to be routinely supported by both parties.

This year, I will not even vote for a Republican running unopposed. This year, I will vote for a straight Democratic ticket from top to bottom. The GOP has been trying its best to destroy the government; has put party before country; and has nominated the worst presidential candidate in American history. Trump is the GOP's Frankenstein, supported only by zombies.

replies.commentBody: We had that the first few years with Obama  he had a Democrat Houses and Senate and all we got for it was Obamacare  our best hope is since HIlary is going to be in the WH the Democrats do not get in control of anything else as for bi partisan  the Democrats don't know how to do that any more as they have shown over the last 10 years

Steve, not true, at least in the Senate. There were long delays in seating Franken, and then there was the loss in MA to fill Kennedy's seat. The Democratic majority in the Senate was really only months.

comments.commentBody: Democratic control of the House?  Republicans should choose between another four years of Total Obstructionism (whatever she tries to pass we say NO like we did with Obama) and the USA continues to go down the tube.. or, in the absence of sensible bipartisan, work-together Republicans, just vote for a Democratic congress and see if they can do better than before!
I'm surprised it is still this close. :)

House and Senate candidates need to be held accountable to do their jobs!  For the Senate this includes holding hearings on Presidential appointees, and for the House it includes not shutting down the government over spending they approved in the first place.

Next 4 weeks?  More baseless allegations by Trump so he has as many excuses as possible if he loses.  Continued failure of the electorate to understand that they will reelect  85-90% of incumbents and all the hue and cry about the change they supposedly want is just hot air by the voters.  There will be no change in Washington gridlock.  More outrageous half true ads will hit the airwaves, all sound and fury signifying nothing.  Lastly, if Hillary wins, it will be the next race between McCain, McConnell and Ryan to see who first can say they will ensure Hillary is a one term president, followed by reaffirmation that Republicans will not approve any Hillary nomination to the Supreme Court (assuming they still control the Senate).

Every Senate and House candidate should be pressed to take a position on Trump's refusal to commit to accept the election result. Will they respect the outcome in their own contest? Do they support Trump's claim that the election is already rigged against him?

Journalists: please make sure that every candidate confronts this issue. We must ensure that everyone in Congress is committed to democracy.

replies.commentBody: GOTV = get out the vote.  Good for you!

comments.commentBody:
Early voting started here today: the lines were long in some places, and there was a short wait at my precinct site.

I was no. 223 at 2:10 pm. A good sign? I hope so. I'm signed up for poll greeting and GOTV stints through Election Day.

I was proud to cast my vote today for the first woman president of the U.S.

How long can Trump speak at rallies and fabricate fantasy land without admitting to his followers that he was puppy whipped by a girl.  Can he say "President Elect Clinton" on November the 8th or 9th.  Can he ever win any negotiation with anyone or borrow a dime. Can he continue to listen to his plastic children and do another TV show presumably called "White Trash on 5th Avenue".   Maybe Rudy, Christie and Trump might find a beaten down bungalow in Patterson, NJ and whittle sticks on the porch.   New Yorkers hate losers so he needs to leave.
